title: Losing! 'MAGA justices' bail out Trump after losing more court cases than any POTUS: Ari Breakdown
description:
The Republicans on the Supreme Court gave Trump an unusual win by limiting judges on how and when they can pause presidential policies, even when they are found to be illegal. MSNBC’s Ari Melber reports on how the move changes the standard rules that governed Trump and President Biden—and how the MAGA-friendly Supreme Court will change and make up rules for Trump’s benefit. title: MSNBC ASKS: D.C. reacts to World Pride 'Celebrated, not tolerated'
description:
The monthlong celebration of LGBTQ Pride reached its peak this past weekend as huge crowds gathered from New York to San Francisco for all-day festivities.

MSNBC spoke with attendees at the WorldPride celebration in Washington, D.C., about why Pride matters now — and what message they have for politicians pushing anti-LGBTQ policies.

For more on this, click the link in our bio to read from the digital series "Finding Pride in a Divided America."

title: LIVE: White House briefs as Senate holds “vote-a-rama” on Trump’s agenda bill
description:
Watch live coverage as White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt holds a press briefing as the Senate is expected to begin a vote-a-rama on the Republican-led reconciliation bill aimed at funding much of Trump's agenda. During the process, the lawmakers will consider an unlimited number of proposed amendments to the legislation, dubbed the "Big, Beautiful Bill." This comes in the wake of Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., announced yesterday that he would not run for re-election, one day after he drew Trump’s ire for opposing the party’s sweeping domestic policy package.

A source close to the Trump family says the President's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, is now considering a run for the seat. Chief Strategist for the Romney 2012 Campaign Stuart Stevens and former White House Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations under the Obama administration Jim Messina join Chris Jansing to share their political analysis.

title: Supreme Court takes up major new challenge to campaign finance restrictions
description:
The Supreme Court has taken up a new challenge to campaign finance restrictions in a case brought by Republicans seeking to overturn limits on party committees spending money in coordination with individual candidates.
The Supreme Court, which has a 6-3 conservative majority, has long been skeptical of campaign finance restrictions on free speech grounds, with its most notable ruling being the 2010 Citizens United v. FEC decision that paved the way for unlimited independent expenditures by outside groups.

title: Nikole Hannah-Jones: Trump is ‘Eradicating the enforcement mechanisms for our civil rights’
description:
Trump has dismantled over 60 years worth of civil rights progress over the course of two months, says Pulitzer-Prize winning journalist and creator of the 1619 Project Nikole Hannah-Jones. While Trump “doesn’t have the ability to overturn the 1964 Civil Rights Act or The Voting Rights Act or The Fair Housing Act,” he’s instead upended civil rights enforcement mechanisms. Which she says, “sends the message that if you discriminate, there’s no one in the federal government that’s going to enforce the law.” The administration is “creating a narrative that allows [for] a stripping of Black people’s rights,” says Hannah-Jones.

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

title: ‘The tools of capitalism can be neutral’: Author Rachel Laryea talks ‘Black Capitalists’
description:
Capitalism is not without its critiques, with good reason, argues Author Rachel Laryea. Despite this, Black Americans continue to navigate under an economic system that historically hasn’t been kind. “We live in contradictory systems every day,” says Dr. Laryea. In “Black Capitalists: A Blueprint for What is Possible,” Laryea redefines what it means to be a Black and a capitalist. While the tools of capitalism have been racialized in the past, they “can be neutral” and provide positive outcomes.

title: Democratic strategist: Racist attacks on Zohran Mamdani obscure the substance of his platform
description:
Since Zohran Mamdani's sweeping victory in the New York City Democratic mayoral primary, GOP lawmakers and leaders have unleashed a barrage of Islamophobic attacks and smears. Democratic strategist Waleed Shahid says that the racist comments obscure and distract from Mamdani's platform. "We are missing an opportunity to engage with the substance of why the plurality of voters chose Zohran Mamdani, which is a conversation about rent, a conversation about groceries, a conversation about public transit in this city," Shahid says.

title: Family of Venezuelan man deported to El Salvador has no idea of his condition
description:
Weeks after undergoing an emergency surgery to remove his right lung, Wladimir Vera Villamizar, a 33-year-old welder from western Venezuela, was deported to El Salvador and locked up in the supermax prison known as the Center for the Confinement of Terrorism, or CECOT. Since then, nothing is known about whether Vera is receiving any treatment, and his family has no idea how he is. NBC’s David Noriega speaks to Alex Witt about the statement he received from the Department of Homeland Security regarding Vera, discusses the alarms raised by doctors about detaining a patient so soon after a rare, major operation, and more.

title: SCOTUS guts nationwide blocks on Trump’s orders
description:
In a new ruling, Trump v. CASA, the Supreme Court’s supermajority limited the ability of federal judges to issue universal injunctions–orders that block potentially unlawful policies nationwide until courts can decide their legality. At the center of the case is Trump’s executive order aimed at ending birthright citizenship, a right guaranteed by the 14th Amendment. Now, the Supreme Court has ruled that in most cases, judges can only block policies for the specific plaintiffs before them– leaving millions unprotected while lawsuits make their way through the courts. The decision fits into the Court’s broader pattern of expanding executive power. 

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

title: ‘More empty homes in America than there are homeless people’: Affordability agenda drives NY primary
description:
Critics debate whether the primary win of Zohran Mamdani is a referendum on the future of the Democratic party. One thing is certain – he clearly struck a nerve with voters, and it’s that Americans can barely afford to live in this country. Author and economics professor Andre Perry argues that nothing will be affordable if wages can’t keep pace with rising costs. He notes that New York City has “lost 75,000 middle income jobs” just in the last year. According to radio show host and NYT best-selling author, Thom Hartmann, the housing crisis has been driven in part by giant corporations buying up properties and driving up costs, stating when prices “you start to see homelessness explode in these communities.”

title: ‘It’s a lawless process’: NYC Comptroller Brad Lander on ICE Arrests at Immigration Courts
description:
Seeing people show up to defend immigrants can inspire doubt and dissent even among those tasked with enforcing ICE’s edicts, says NYC Comptroller Brad Lander, who was arrested by Immigration and Customs Enforcement at a Manhattan immigration court on June 17, revealing that “the ICE agent who arrested me confessed to me afterwards that his wife hopes he quits his job.” Lander, who also ran in the Democratic primary for New York City mayor, was one of many people across the country, including a Catholic bishop in San Diego and National Guard members in Chicago, who are accompanying immigrants to their hearings in response to ICE’s new tactic of arresting people on their way to and from court proceedings. The comptroller describes seeing people detained by ICE agents after being given asylum hearing dates and encourages Americans to show up and bear witness. “You have the right to sit in the courtroom and see what's happening, and that's your right as a person in this democracy,” Lander says.

title: Velshi Banned Book Club: “World War Z” by Max Brooks
description:
Max Brooks’ seminal zombie thriller, “World War Z”, is set in an alternate 21st century world after a zombie apocalypse -- a pandemic that began in a small Chinese village -- infected and subsequently killed millions. Told through a series of interviews, all conducted by a fictional version of Brooks, there is very intentionally no hero. Each interview subject is a survivor of the apocalypse, each with a different role to play. While “World War Z” grapples with human shortsightedness, the power of fear, the fragility of modern life, the necessity of humanity in the face of chaos, at its core, it is a book about survival.

title: ‘We will be in court every single day’: Attorneys share pushback strategy after birthright ruling
description:
Yesterday's Supreme Court decision was a huge win for President Trump, not just regarding his efforts to end automatic birthright citizenship but in concentrating more power into the presidency. The 6-3 ruling from the conservative majority Supreme Court limited the ability of lower courts to issue nationwide injunctions – one of the key tools that the judicial branch had in its checks and balances on an executive branch that they believe is exceeding its lawful authority. Andrea Flores, Vice President for Immigration Policy and Campaigns at FWD.US and Skye Perryman, President & CEO of Democracy Forward join The Weekend to discuss their plan to handle litigation following the Supreme Court’s birthright citizenship ruling.

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

title: 'Disinformation from the top down': Judge Salas calls out political attacks on judiciary
description:
U.S. District Judge Esther Salas, whose son was murdered in a targeted attack in 2020, joins Morning Joe following the “Speak Up for Justice” forum, where judges from around the world warned against growing threats to the legal system: “Disinformation is being used from the top down” to portray judges as corrupt... “If the government doesn't like our rulings, appeal to a higher court. The answer is not to threaten or denigrate the entire justice system.”

Retired Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy also spoke at the event, urging Americans to reject toxic political discourse and defend the rule of law.

The Supreme Court ruled parents can opt children out of reading LGBTQ+ books in schools. GLAAD President and CEO Sarah Kate Ellis joins Chris Jansing to share her reaction, saying the Court is prioritizing the rights of a small group in order to “segregate” LGBTQ+ families.

title: Travel advisory: Don’t share this Vance meme
description:
'I strongly recommend that you do not try to cross the border with this meme on your phone."
MSNBC's Catherine Rampell reports on a recent story of a Norwegian tourist who says he was detained and denied entry to the U.S. because immigration officials found on his phone a photo depicting Vice President JD Vance as a bald baby.
U.S. Customs and Border Protection disputes the claim, saying that the tourist was denied entry because of his "admitted drug use."

title: SCOTUS allows Trump admin. to take steps to implement end to birthright citizenship
description:
The Supreme Court has just announced the birthright citizenship case opinion, with a 6-3 ruling, following party lines. This means Trump’s executive order curtailing birthright citizenship will be allowed in certain states but not others. MSNBC Legal Correspondent Lisa Rubin, former U.S. Attorney Chuck Rosenberg and University of Michigan Assistant Professor of Law Leah Litman join Ana Cabrera to break down the ruling, noting Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson called it “an existential threat to the rule of law” in her dissent.

title: Trump's NEW legal NIGHTMARE
description:
Democratic state attorneys general have filed dozens of lawsuits against the Trump administration and are showing no signs of stopping. From the fight over the Department of Transportation's withholding of funding because of immigration-related disputes to the battle to restore federal health research grants — state AGs are playing offense, not defense. MSNBC Legal Correspondent Lisa Rubin sits down with three of the AGs taking on Trump — Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison; Illinois Attorney General Kwame Raoul; and New Jersey Attorney General Matthew Platkin. They recently testified at a forum on Capitol Hill titled “Defending the Rights of the People” about their role in combating Trump 2.0 through litigation.

title: Live: Trump hosts "Everyday Americans" event to promote GOP bill
description:
Watch live coverage as President Donald Trump holds an event at the White House to promote the Republicans' sweeping domestic policy legislation, which the president and others have dubbed "the one big, beautiful bill," as senators consider changes to the House-passed legislation. The event will focus on urging the Senate to pass the legislation and will feature everyday Americans — including a delivery driver, border state resident, sheriff and flight attendant — who the White House says will benefit from the bill. Any changes by the Senate would need to go through the House again. The bill has divided GOP lawmakers over its potential impact on Medicaid and the national deficit.

title: ‘This guy is a joke’: Michael Steele on Trump judicial nominee

title: "Did you suggest telling the courts 'f--- you?'": Schiff presses Trump judge pick in hearing
description:
"It seems to me that would be something you'd remember, unless that's the kind of thing you say frequently."

Senator Adam Schiff (D-CA) pressed Emil Bove — a former Trump defense attorney and current DOJ official nominated for a circuit court judgeship — over allegations that he encouraged DOJ lawyers to ignore court orders to advance the president’s agenda.

When asked about whistleblower claims that he told DOJ staffers to say “f--- you” to the courts, Bove said he had “no recollection” of making such a statement. He acknowledged, however, that he has encouraged department litigators to “fight hard for valid positions that we have to take in defense of our clients.”

title: Trump nominee Bove faces Senate following claim he was willing to defy courts
description:
Justice Department official Emil Bove faced sharp questions from Democratic lawmakers as he appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee on his nomination by President Trump to serve on a federal appeals court. Information has emerged that further puts Bove’s character at issue. As first reported by The New York Times on Tuesday and confirmed by NBC News, Bove told subordinates he was willing to ignore court orders to carry out the president’s deportation campaign. Bove is seeking a lifetime judicial appointment — as a federal appeals court judge, to be exact, just a step below the Supreme Court.
For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

An initial assessment by the Defense Intelligence Agency concludes that the U.S. airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear enrichment sites over the weekend were not as effective as President Donald Trump said and that they set the country's nuclear program back by only three to six months, according to three people with knowledge of the report. Meanwhile, the president is doubling down on claiming the sites were totally obliterated.

title: 'Heartbroken' and 'betrayed': Marine vet speaks out on father beaten by ICE agents
description:
After Narciso Barranco, a landscaper in California, was pinned down and violently detained by federal immigration agents, his son — who has served in the U.S. Marine Corps — is speaking out about what happened to his father.
NBC News' Jacob Soboroff spoke to Alejandro Barranco, who said he feels "heartbroken" and "betrayed" by what happened.
In a statement, a spokesperson for the Department of Homeland Security said Barranco "refused to comply every step of the way" and that agents used "the minimum amount of force necessary to resolve the situation."

title: Sources say strikes on Iran set back its nuclear program only several months
description:
An initial assessment by the Defense Intelligence Agency concludes that the U.S. airstrikes conducted over the weekend on Iran’s nuclear enrichment sites were not as effective as President Donald Trump said and only set the country's nuclear program back by three to six months, according to three people with knowledge of the report. The assessment’s conclusions were first reported by CNN.
NBC News justice and intelligence correspondent, Ken Dilanian, breaks down the new reporting.

title: Chris Hayes: Trump’s “distorted, refracted, reality” shaped by content intake
description:
It can be pretty difficult to tell what’s real from what’s not online. From AI videos being posted online by everyday people to President Trump posting photoshopped content, trying to parse through what’s fake from what’s not can feel a bit confusing to say the least. Jia Tolentino, a staff writer at the New Yorker, wrote a piece all about this titled, “My Brain Finally Broke.” In the essay, she points out that much of the world is “slipping beyond [her] comprehension.” Tolentino joins “Why Is This Happening? The Chris Hayes podcast to discuss how AI is changing our perception of the world, how online content can make us more likely to detach from reality and more. Note: this episode was recorded on 6/11/25.

title: LIVE: RFK Jr. testifies before House amid concerns on vaccine policy and public health
description:
Watch live coverage as Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. testifies before a House subcommittee regarding the Trump administration’s proposed budget. The proposed budget includes significant cuts to the National Institute of Health, including research, something experts have said would set back medical progress and harm public health. Kennedy’s “Make America Healthy Again” movement has proved controversial. Supporters have praised his efforts to remove artificial dyes from food and his efforts to reinvestigate vaccines. But critics have raised the alarm about Kennedy’s rejection of decades of data on vaccine safety and other dubious medical advice he has given.

title: DOJ whistleblower accuse Trump judge pick of intending to defy court orders
description:
Erez Reuveni, a former DOJ lawyer who was dismissed after admitting the Trump administration made a mistake by deporting Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, is accusing Trump federal judge pick Emil Bove of being willing to defy court orders in order to advance the president's agenda.
According to a report by the New York Times, Reuveni said in meetings surrounding the use of the Alien Enemies Act by the administration to deport undocumented people, Bove proposed violating court orders, telling staff that the DOJ would need to consider telling courts "f--- you."
NBC News' Ken Dilanian has the latest.

title: 'It's not clear to me what the admin. is hiding from the Congress': Jeffries on U.S. Iran strikes
description:
House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., said that he has requested a briefing for top lawmakers in Congress on the situation in Iran, but one hasn't happened yet. He then accused the Trump administration of hiding information related to Iran from Congress.

“And it’s not clear to me what the administration is hiding from the Congress and from the American people,” Jeffries said. “If they have a case to make, come up to Capitol Hill and make it.”

Asked for comment, the White House pointed to remarks this morning from press secretary Karoline Leavitt who told reporters that Trump officials did call Democrats about the situation in Iran. The White House, however, didn't address whether a formal briefing would be provided as they typically take place on Capitol Hill amid major events.

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

They talk about Trump’s playbook of distraction, the Fox News effect,  what AOC and Bernie Sanders are doing that Democrats should “emulate” and why the opposition and resistance to Trump has them “optimistic.”

title: Iran threatened to unleash attacks by sleeper cells inside U.S. if it was attacked
description:
Iran sent a communiqué to Trump in the days before last night's strikes on its nuclear facilities threatening to activate sleeper-cell terror inside the United States if it were attacked, sources said.
The message got to Trump through an intermediary at the G7 summit in Canada last week, which Trump left early June 16 to consider his options amid the conflict between Israel and Iran, according to sources who include two U.S. officials and a person with knowledge of the threat.

title: Trump posts 'Make Iran Great Again'
description:
President Donald Trump raised the prospect of regime change in Iran in a Truth Social post, though he stopped short of explicitly saying the U.S. would pursue it. “It’s not politically correct to use the term ‘Regime Change,’ but if the current Iranian Regime is unable to MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN, why wouldn’t there be a Regime change??? MIGA!!!” he wrote. The post marked a shift in tone from senior administration officials. Gabe Gutierrez reports.

description:

title: DHS warns of 'heightened threat environment' in U.S. following Iran strikes
description:
The Department of Homeland Security issued a new bulletin today warning of a "heightened threat environment" following the U.S. strikes on nuclear facilities in Iran.

The bulletin warns that "low-level cyber attacks against US networks by pro-Iranian hacktivists are likely, and cyber actors affiliated with the Iranian government may conduct attacks against US networks." DHS also warns of possible violence by independent actors. Gabe Gutierrez reports.

title: Bad Bunny slams ICE
description:
Puerto Rican rapper and singer Bad Bunny calls out ICE on Instagram. “Look, those motherf**kers are in these cars, RAV-4s. They’re here in Pontezuela. Sons of b***hes, instead of leaving the people alone and working there,” he said in Spanish in a video posted to his Instagram Stories.

NPR reports that ICE has adopted more aggressive tactics in Puerto Rico under the current Trump administration. In an interview with the outlet, Rebecca González-Ramos, head of Homeland Security Investigations in Puerto Rico, said nearly 500 immigrants have been arrested for deportation on the island over the past four months.

It’s unclear whether those filmed in Bad Bunny’s Instagram video were federal agents or if an ICE operation was underway.

description:

title: Juneteenth amid Trump’s Anti-DEI Agenda: 'Latest iteration of a country trying to forget its past'
description:
Amid the Trump administration’s anti-diversity, equity and inclusion agenda, Black Americans gathered in cities across America to celebrate Juneteenth. On a holiday that commemorates the ending of slavery, Trump chose to gripe that there are “too many non-working holidays.” “What we’re seeing right now is the latest iteration of a country trying to forget its past,“ laments Princeton’s Eddie Glaude – trying to disremember”. But whether the Trump administration recognizes Juneteenth or not, “this tradition that’s been a part of African American history will continue on.” That resilience, according to Fordham’s Christina Greer, follows a long history of Black Americans “finding joy” where they can.

title: Velshi Banned Book Club: ‘Olive’s Ocean’ by Kevin Henkes
description:
Olive's Ocean by the multiple award-winning author Kevin Henkes (also of ‘Chrysanthemum’, ‘Lilly’s Purple Plastic Purse,’ and others) grapples with family dynamics, death, and the healing power of nature – but at its core, it's a coming of age story. It's an examination of how intrinsically linked adolescence and mortality are – more specifically, the awareness of mortality. It is hard to believe that this book spent nearly a decade climbing the American Library Association's List of 100 most challenged books. Including just a few curse words and a single allusion to sex made by Martha's 14 year old brother, the book is a window into young people's lives. “It's about the enduring bonds of family, the wisdom of the older generation, the importance of not judging someone and prejudging them and getting to know them,” says Henkes. “It's about a kid who's trying to figure out where she belongs, a kid who's trying to be understood. And the love is the operating principle – the foundation and the spine that supports everything.”

title: WATCH: White House briefs as Trump weighs U.S. military strikes against Iran
description:
Watch live coverage as White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt holds a press briefing after President Donald Trump said he was still considering a U.S. military strike on Iran’s nuclear sites. “I may do it. I may not do it,” he said to reporters on Wednesday, adding, “nobody knows what I’m going to do.” As the conflict entered its seventh day, Israel said that overnight it targeted Iran's Arak nuclear reactor and a nuclear weapons development site in Natanz. Israel said it would "increase the intensity of attacks" after a hospital in the southern part of the country was directly hit by an Iranian missile. Iran says it was aiming for a nearby military complex.

title: SpaceX Starship 36 explodes during test in Texas
description: A SpaceX Starship prototype exploded during a static-fire test late Wednesday night at the company’s Starbase facility in Boca Chica, Texas. SpaceX CEO Elon Musk said the cause may have been a nitrogen pressure vessel failure in the upper stage. No injuries were reported, and safety zones protected nearby communities. This marks the fourth Starship lost in 2025 as SpaceX continues rapid testing under FAA oversight.

title: 'A lot of worry inside the Pentagon' as Trump weighs U.S. strike on Iran: Analyst
description:

title: Sen. Slotkin on Hegseth DODGING question on if he'd given the order to ‘shoot at unarmed protesters'
description:
Sen. Elissa Slotkin, D-Mich., questioned Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing about any orders he has given to the military in the deployment of troops to handle protests in Los Angeles in response to immigration actions by the administration.
During the hearing, Slotkin said she was asking because Trump's defense secretary during his first term, Mark Esper, rejected such an order from Trump during protests after the death of George Floyd.
She joined Nicolle Wallace on "Deadline: White House" to discuss her reaction to his response.

title: Obama warns the U.S. is ‘dangerously close’ to slipping into autocracy under Trump
description:
Former President Barack Obama issued a warning about the future of American democracy, cautioning that the country is “dangerously close” to normalizing behavior “consistent with autocracies.”
Speaking at an event in Hartford, Connecticut, he offered thinly veiled criticism of President Donald Trump and questioned the administration’s commitment to democracy.
“If you follow regularly what is said by those who are in charge of the federal government right now, there is a weak commitment to what we understood — and not just my generation, at least since World War II — our understanding of how a liberal democracy is supposed to work."

title: Joe: Gabbard's 'bizarre' video shows 'deep divide in the MAGA base'
description:
On Morning Joe, John Heilemann and Joe Scarborough reacted to a new rift between Donald Trump and his intel chief, Tulsi Gabbard, after Gabbard released an unsanctioned video warning the U.S. is “on the brink of nuclear annihilation.” Gabbard’s message, which criticized “political elite and warmongers,” reportedly caught the Trump White House off guard—and fueled a growing divide inside the MAGA base over U.S. involvement in Iran.

title: Senator presses Defense Sec'y on plans to deploy troops to more U.S. cities
description:
Senator Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) presses Secretary Hegseth on the use of active duty military troops in Los Angeles for law enforcement purposes and whether or not the Department of Defense has created contingency plans to deploy troops to other cities across the country. "We can be alarmed by the attacks on ICE officers, yes," said Sen. Blumenthal, "but, we ought ought to be equally alarmed by the illegal use of active duty Marines or other military."

title: Supreme Court says Tennessee’s ban on gender-affirming care for minors is constitutional
description:
The Supreme Court upheld a Tennessee law restricting gender transition care for minors, delivering a major blow to transgender rights. The 6-3 ruling is likely to have a broad impact as 24 other states have already enacted laws similar to the one in Tennessee, which bars gender transition surgery, puberty blockers and hormone therapy for youth. NBC News Legal Correspondent Lisa Rubin explains.

description:

Jen Psaki reports on yet another public official being arrested by ICE in the course of their heavy-handed tactics in rounding up immigrants. But each new instance of abuse of power by ICE is met with more vocal outrage and louder public protests.

title: Reality makes a mockery of Donald Trump's 'peacemaker' ambitions
description:
Jen Psaki looks back at Donald Trump's repeated campaign pledges to oppose war as president, including very specifically ending the war between Russia and Ukraine. Now, just a few months into his second term, Trump seems to be associating the United States with Israel's war on Iran, and Trump's "peacemaker" promises appear to be empty.

title: 'They knew who I was': NYC Comptroller Lander describes arrest at federal courthouse
description:
"There's no doubt they knew I was the comptroller." New York City Comptroller Brad Lander speaks with Chris Hayes on All In after his arrest in connection with an episode at a federal courthouse in the city, where Lander and his wife said they were serving as advocates for defendants in immigration court.
The Department of Homeland Security said Lander, a mayoral candidate, had been arrested for "assaulting law enforcement and impeding a federal officer." Lander denied assaulting law enforcement.

title: 'Violent rhetoric' and 'misinformation': Wallace reacts to controversial posts on Minnesota attacks
description:
"A confrontation in the hallways of Capitol Hill...is speaking volumes today about the toxic stew that permeates there. It's a mix of violent rhetoric and distrust and misinformation and right-wing information bubbles that is eating away at the foundations of the US Capitol and our democracy."

MSNBC's Nicolle Wallace shares her reaction to reports that Sen. Tina Smith, D-Minn., confronted Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah, over controversial social media posts about the fatal attack on a Minnesota lawmaker and her husband. Sen. Lee later removed those posts on his personal X account.

title: 'The stuff of nightmares' U.S. attorney announces charges against 'political assassination' suspect
description:
Acting U.S. Attorney for the District of Minnesota Joseph Thompson said Vance Boelter arrived at the Champlin home of state Sen. John Hoffman and his wife, Yvette Hoffman, in a black SUV with emergency lights turned on and a license plate that read "police."

Boelter was allegedly disguised as a police officer and dressed in a black tactical vest and body armor. Thompson said he was carrying a flashlight and a handgun and wearing a "hyper realistic" silicone mask. "Sen. Hoffman had a security camera. I’ve seen the footage from that camera, and it is chilling," Thompson said.

title: 'Big mistake': Trump on kicking Russia/Putin out of then-G8
description:
Ahead of the G7 Summit in Alberta, Canada, President Trump told reporters that it was a "big mistake" for Russia to have been kicked out of the then-G8, which took place after Russia invaded Crimea.

"[Putin] doesn't even speak to the people that threw him out. And I agree with him," Trump said.

The president has previously criticized Russia's removal from the group of leading industrialized nations. Trump said he did not believe there would have been a war between Russia and Ukraine if Russia were still part of the group.

title: LIVE: Trump meets with Canada PM Carney ahead of G7 Summit | NBC News
description:
Watch live coverage as President Trump kicks off the first full day of his trip to Canada with a meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, which comes amid heightened tensions over trade and the president referring to Canada as the 51st state. The two leaders previously met when Carney visited the White House in May. The president then heads into G7 sessions, which are taking place in Alberta, Canada, near Calgary. World leaders are gathering for the annual conference, where they will discuss top international issues. The G7 is composed of the U.S., Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan, but leaders from a handful of other countries, including Ukraine, will attend this week’s meeting, as well.

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

title: 'Simply outrageous': Napolitano on Trump federalizing the CA National Guard
description:
As former Homeland Security Secretary and former governor of a border state, Janet Napolitano has experienced what’s broken about America’s immigration system. And, she argues, there are ways to fix it. But what Donald Trump is doing is no solution. Federalizing California’s National guard was “simply outrageous,” she says. And the president’s decision to deploy active duty Marines to the streets of Los Angeles to quell protests against ICE raids “is really crossing a red line.” She makes the case that a multi-prong approach is needed, including congressional reform. "We have to decide on some way that those who have been in the country in an undocumented fashion, for years, many of them, can somehow get right with the law so that we're not breaking up families."

title: Resistance or bust: Military troops in U.S. cities signal a national inflection point
description:
Thousands of U.S. troops have been deployed to Los Angeles in response to largely peaceful demonstrations against ICE raids. Donald Trump’s presidential memo authorizing the National Guard's deployment stops short of invoking the Insurrection Act. But the legal debate over whether he’s formally invoked it may be beside the point. In practice, Trump is already behaving as if he holds those emergency powers. Author and radio host Thom Hartmann warns this is an inflection point for the country. America’s current oligarchic phase will give way to one of two paths, he argues: full-blown autocracy, or mass resistance. And when that resistance begins, Hartmann says, the oligarchs face a choice: “Are we going to bring down the fist—or are we going to back off? And so far, what we are seeing is the fist.” This moment, Hartmann adds, is a moment of decision–“for the country, for the oligarchs, and for all of us.”

title: Minn. lawmaker shot in "politically motivated assassination," another wounded
description:
#Minnesota House Democratic Leader Melissa Hortman and her spouse, Mark, were fatally shot Saturday morning. A second lawmaker, State Sen. John Hoffman, and his spouse were also shot at their home in eastern Minnesota, officials said. Gov. Tim Walz said the attack appears to be "targeted political violence." The assailant remains at large and reportedly impersonated a police officer with a uniform and a cruiser. A manhunt is underway.

title: Enormous pushback: Nearly two-thirds of Americans oppose funding Trump’s military parade
description:
According to a brand new NBC News Decision Desk Poll out this morning, 64% of Americans oppose the use of government funds for the parade. Meanwhile, in very different scenes playing out across the country, organizers are staging protests in hundreds of cities and towns in what they are calling a nationwide day of defiance. The protests come during a week of heightened tensions over President Trump's immigration raids, a week that saw Democratic Sen. Alex Padilla of California forcibly removed from DHS Sec. Kristi Noem's press conference on Thursday.

title: U.S. Marines reportedly detain man outside L.A. federal building
description:
NEW: Video from news agency Reuters appears to show a man being detained outside the Westwood Federal Building in Los Angeles.
Reuters said it was the first detention by a U.S. Marine during the deployment for area protests over immigration enforcement. It's not clear why the man was detained.
U.S. Northern Command confirmed the detention by U.S. Marines, saying it was temporary and justified under the assignment to protect federal assets, which include the property formally known as the 11000 Wilshire Federal Building. A spokesperson said the man was immediately transferred to the custody of local law enforcement, as allowed.

title: Rep. McIver reacts to Trump's border czar: Facts are 'going to be on my side' in Newark incident
description:
Rep. LaMonica McIver, D-N.J., joined Ari Melber on “The Beat” after being indicted on federal charges stemming from a confrontation with law enforcement at an ICE facility in Newark.
She responded to comments made by Trump's border czar, Tom Homan, on the case: "All of the facts are gonna come out and they're gonna be on my side when it gets to that point," McIver said.
The interim U.S. attorney for New Jersey, Alina Habba, said on X of the indictment that, “While people are free to express their views for or against particular policies, they must not do so in a manner that endangers law enforcement and the communities those officers serve.

title: 'I don't believe it': Sole Indian plane crash survivor speaks
description:
The survivor of the Air India Flight 171 crash revealed he miraculously survived by escaping through a broken emergency exit.
"I can't believe myself how I came out of it alive, because for a while I thought I was going to die as well," Ramesh Viswashkumar, 40, told Indian national broadcaster DD News. "But when I opened my eyes, I saw that I was alive. So I tried to open my seat belt, and I was able to get out."
There were 242 people on board the Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner, bound for London, that crashed shortly after takeoff in the western Indian city of Ahmedabad, smashing in a fiery blast into a medical college hostel.

title: Four detainees at Newark immigration facility have escaped, DHS said
description:
Four people detained at an immigration detention center in Newark, New Jersey have escaped, according to the Department of Homeland Security.
The detainees were being held at the Delaney Hall facility, where Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has been holding individuals who are facing possible deportation. The four people were unaccounted for Thursday night, and federal authorities were looking into whether they were still on the grounds of the facility, or had somehow escaped, senior officials said.

title: Sen. Padilla (D-CA) forcibly removed from DHS press conf., pushed to the ground
description:
WATCH: Sen. Alex Padilla (D-CA) was forcibly removed from Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem's press conference in Los Angeles.

Padilla's office shared a video of the incident with NBC News. The video shows Padilla being taken into a hallway outside and pushed face forward onto the ground as officers with FBI-identifying vests told the senator to put his hands behind his back. The officers then handcuffed him.

According to a statement from Padilla's office, "He tried to ask the Secretary a question, and was forcibly removed by federal agents, forced to the ground and handcuffed. He is not currently detained."

In a statement posted to social media, DHS said “Senator Padilla chose disrespectful political theatre and interrupted a live press conference without identifying himself or having his Senate security pin on as he lunged toward Secretary Noem.”

title: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott deploys over 5,000 National Guard troops
description:
Texas Gov. Greg Abbott announced that he has deployed more than 5,000 National Guard troops to quell protests throughout the state.

In a news release, the governor said 2,000 Texas Department of Public Safety troopers have also been deployed ahead of expected weekend protests over Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids.

"Anyone engaging in acts of violence or damaging property will be arrested and held accountable to the full extent of the law. Don’t mess with Texas — and don’t mess with Texas law enforcement," Abbott said in the press release.

title: One survivor reported in India crash that kills more than 200
description:
Indian media reports say that a British national survived the crash. NBC News has cross checked the flight manifest and confirmed the name of the man and the seat number match those reported by local media. 

Family members have confirmed to Sky News that British national Vishwash Kumar Ramesh survived the plane crash in Ahmedabad this morning. Family have not heard from another family member who they believe was on the flight.

description:
Marine corps veteran Rep. Jake Auchincloss talks with Jen Psaki about why Donald Trump's use of the U.S. military in his domestic anti-immigrant crusade and in response to protests is wildly inappropriate and contrary to the Constitution, and put U.S. Marines in an impossible position. "They swear an oath to uphold the Constitution. They also swear an oath to obey orders from the president. Right now the president is ordering them to do something that does not support the Constitution."

title: LIVE: Pete Hegseth faces lawmakers on Capitol Hill amid Trump's Marine deployment to L.A.
description:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth will testify on Capitol Hill for the first time since he was confirmed as Pentagon chief. Hegseth, who has had a rocky few months in his Cabinet post, is expected to discuss the military budget for next year in front of the House Appropriations Subcommittee. NBC News reported yesterday that the White House has struggled to hire senior advisers to Hegseth, with three people rejecting potential roles and Vice President JD Vance and White House chief of staff Susie Wiles poring over potential candidates on his behalf. Hegseth came under intense criticism after media reports that he shared sensitive information about a U.S. military operation in Yemen on Signal group chats, including one that inadvertently had a journalist added to it.

title: No ideas, no skills: Maddow rips panicking Trump for rushing to military last resort in L.A.
description:
Rachel Maddow points out that the most important story of our era is not what Donald Trump is trying to do, but what the American people will allow him to do. Maddow notes that pushback works against Trump's authoritarian overreach, and the fact that Trump skipped ahead to the last resort of calling in the military against protesters in Los Angeles is a sign of his weakness, his lack of ideas, and his lack of political skills to turn his plummeting popularity around.

title: Jeffries: Trump should be 'ASHAMED' and has 'zero credibility' on law and order
description:
Watch as House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., holds a press conference and speaks out about the protests in California amid federal ICE raids. Jeffries expressed support for California Governor Gavin Newsom and Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass and claimed the GOP has "zero credibility" on law-and-order issues. “Thankful for the leadership of Governor Newsom and Mayor Bass in terms of managing a fragile situation that Donald Trump and the extreme MAGA Republicans are intentionally trying to inflame. They should be ashamed of themselves. And these people have zero credibility, zero credibility on the other side of the aisle when it comes to issues of law and order,” Jeffries said.

"They should be ashamed of themselves. And these people have zero credibility, zero credibility on the other side of the aisle when it comes to issues of law and order."
House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., said Trump and the current Republican Party are “intentionally trying to inflame” the situation in California amid federal ICE raids.

title: 'They talk about the chaos in L.A. This is a lawless administration': Congressman
description:
Members of the California National Guard have arrived in Los Angeles Sunday morning in response to days of protest against federal immigration raids. On Saturday, President Donald Trump moved to deploy the 2,000 members over the opposition of California Gov. Gavin Newsom and L.A. Mayor Karen Bass, who say the move is inflammatory and unnecessary. California Congressman Jimmy Gomez, whose district is in Los Angeles, spoke out about the move and much more.

title: Gov. Newsom tells President Trump to 'stand down' amid L.A. protests
description:
In an exclusive interview with NBC News' Jacob Soboroff, California Governor Gavin Newsom said that President Trump "has created the conditions" surrounding the Los Angeles protests. The governor went on to call Trump's decision to deploy the National Guard "a manufactured crisis," then addressed White House border czar Tom Homan's threats of arrest. "Tom, arrest me. Let's go," Newsom said.

title: Evan Osnos: Billionaire influence in politics ‘doesn’t look a whole lot like democracy’
description:
Donald Trump, the president of the United States, is a billionaire. He got elected with the help of Elon Musk, the world’s richest man. Trump then appointed thirteen of his fellow billionaires to his cabinet. The rich are richer than ever, and their influence over politics and society is greater than ever. Evan Osnos, staff writer for The New Yorker and author of the new book “The Haves and the Have-Yachts: Dispatches on the Ultrarich” says that when billionaires have so much sway, “that doesn’t look a whole lot like democracy.” While Trump and Musk may be at odds now, Osnos notes that Musk’s complaints about the president sound “like he was complaining about buying a defective product.” Musk’s recent comments, Osnos says, may read to future historians as “the Rosetta Stone of how our democracy got so damaged.” -

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

title: Trump wants 'these images, but it's for all the wrong reasons': analyst
description:
Members of the California National Guard arrived in Los Angeles Sunday morning in response to Friday and Saturday's protest against federal immigration raids.  President Donald Trump moved to deploy the 2,000 members over the opposition of California Gov. Gavin Newsom and L.A. Mayor Karen Bass, who called the move inflammatory and unnecessary.  Julian Castro, former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and now an MSNBC political analyst, along with Don Calloway, host of The Caucus Room Podcast and CEO of Pine Street Strategies, and republican strategist and MSNBC political analyst Susan Del Percio discuss these latest developments, and more.

title: ‘It’s violently anti-woman’: Melissa Murray reflects on the criminalization of miscarriage
description:
One in five women experience a miscarriage according to the National Institutes of Health, and now women who suffer pregnancy loss can face prosecution. One prosecutor in West Virginia even went so far as to suggest women call law enforcement after having a miscarriage to avoid prosecution. Amanda Zurawski, lead plaintiff in the Texas case that included 20 women who were denied emergency care, called this suggestion “reprehensible” and “terrifying.” NYU Professor Melissa Murray says that if having an abortion is going to be considered criminal behavior, that prosecutor just invited pregnant women to incriminate themselves.

title: Magic dust and mayhem: The Great GOP Panic over Trump’s ‘Big Beautiful Bill’
description:
Trump’s so-called “Big Beautiful Bill” narrowly passed the House by a single vote and is now stalled in the Senate. We take a closer look at this massive tax plan that gives permanent breaks for the wealthy while slashing Medicaid, food assistance, and clean energy programs. According to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, it would add at least $2.4 trillion to the national deficit–hardly a win for fiscal conservatives. Even Elon Musk slammed it as a “disgusting abomination.” Meanwhile, Republican economists call out its fantasy math, while many GOP senators worry about the political backlash back home.

title: Velshi Banned Book Club: ‘Animal Farm’ by George Orwell
description:
When the animals on Manor Farm overthrow the farmer who lords over them, they dream of a utopia built on an inclusive mission: all animals are equal. But power is corrupting, and soon an autocratic pig seizes control and imposes a new creed on the farm: All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others. That is the premise of today’s Velshi Banned Book Club feature, one of the most salient political satires ever written: “Animal Farm” by George Orwell. Orwell’s masterful command of language, his dynamic and complex anthropomorphic characters, and well-paced plot are precision instruments used to sharply warn its reader of the corrupting influence of power, the danger of blind obedience, and the cyclical nature of politics. As Téa Obreht, author of the foreword for the 75th anniversary edition of “Animal Farm”, says, “The book is a warning in the clearest possible way, through animal fable, that [authoritarianism] can happen everywhere.”

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

title: Trump dumps the Federalist Society — and even Republicans are shooketh
description:
In a major about-face, Donald Trump is turning on the conservative powerhouse that built his judicial legacy, the Federalist Society. Yale Law professor Akhil Reed Amar warns that this break with the very group that helped propel him to power marks a dangerous shift. “He just wants loyalty to himself—thugs and hacks,” Amar says, adding that Federalist Society judges are principled and loyal to the Constitution, not to Trump. “The Senate needs to play a really important role now—especially now that he’s showing his cards.” Trump’s latest nominee, his own defense lawyer Emil Bove, has drawn sharp criticism, including from conservative circles. “It’s one thing to put people in your branch, in your cabinet—but we’re talking about life-appointed judges and justices,” Amar warns.

title: ‘Republican math never works’: Former GOP Congressman slams Trump budget bill
description:
President Trump's big agenda bill is facing some serious resistance from Republicans, especially after it was revealed the bill would add $2.4 trillion to the national debt over the next 10 years, according to an estimate from the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office. That’s even without his new frenemy Elon Musk's opposition. Former GOP Congressman and Democratic Florida gubernatorial candidate David Jolly joins The Weekend along with White House press office chief of staff Yemisi Egbewole to discuss.

title: White House ‘couldn’t believe’ what was happening between Trump-Musk
description:

NBC News' Senior Investigative Producer Sarah Fitzpatrick explains Musk is distracting from the problem of the day as “online bot groups connected to our foreign adversaries” are picking up on key phrases such as “Epstein files.” Atlantic staff writer Ashley Parker and Financial Times columnist Gillian Tett also join Katy Tur to dive into Musk's strategy.

title: Trump describes D-Day as 'not a great day' to German chancellor
description:
During a White House visit Thursday, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz invoked D-Day and its significance. President Trump replied that it was “not a pleasant day” for the chancellor.

On the 81st anniversary, #MorningJoe historian Jon Meacham called D-Day “the hinge of the 20th century” and urged Americans to reflect on its legacy: “They almost got it wrong, and then they got it right. And that gives us, I think, hope.”

title: Wallace on Trump and Musk FEUD: The 'most corrupt and superficial alliance' in history
description:
"The alliance between the world's richest man and the world's most powerful Donald Trump is imploding right now in real time before our very eyes." Nicolle Wallace explains the feud between President Donald Trump and Elon Musk and why she says it affirms "our deepest concerns and suspicions."
Musk’s tweet on “the Epstein files” is part of a recent and broader dispute. Trump has denied any involvement and Musk offered no evidence to back up his claim. The White House responded saying “This is an unfortunate episode from Elon, who is unhappy with the One Big Beautiful Bill because it does not include the policies he wanted."

title: SCOTUS unanimously sides with straight woman in 'reverse discrimination' appeal
description:
In a unanimous decision, the Supreme Court revived a woman's claim that she was discriminated against at work because she is straight. The unanimous ruling could make it easier in some parts of the country for people belonging to majority groups to bring such “reverse discrimination” claims. It overturns precedent in some lower courts that says someone from a majority group has to meet a higher bar than someone from a minority group for a case to move forward.
Marlean Ames sued the Ohio Department of Youth Services under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, which prohibits sex discrimination in the workplace, after a lesbian woman obtained a promotion she had applied for. She was later demoted, and her old position was taken by a gay man.

title: Trump and China’s president agree to new in-person meeting after phone call
description:
President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping held a phone call amid ongoing tensions between the two superpowers — with a new in-person meeting planned soon.
In a Truth Social post, Trump said the call lasted about 90 minutes, but provided few details about it other than that it focused on trade. He said a meeting will now be held "shortly" between representatives from the two nations at a location to be determined.
It’s the first known call between the two leaders in Trump’s second term, though the two spoke in January before Trump’s inauguration.

title: Trump signs order banning travel from 12 countries
description:
President Donald Trump signed a proclamation that bans nationals from a dozen countries, including Afghanistan, Haiti and the Republic of Congo, from entering the United States, framing the travel ban as necessary to fortify national security and building upon one of the most contentious policies of his first term.
Trump banned nationals from 12 countries from entering the United States: Afghanistan, Burma, Chad, Republic of Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Haiti, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen.
An additional seven countries came under partial travel restrictions, in which entrance into the country under several visa programs was suspended but an outright ban was not implemented: Burundi, Cuba, Laos, Sierra Leone, Togo, Turkmenistan and Venezuela.

title: Rep. DeLauro to WH budget chief: 'You are living in a legal and historical fiction'
description:
Rep. Rosa DeLauro, D-Conn., sharply criticized Office of Management and Budget Director Russell Vought during a House Appropriations Subcommittee on Financial Services and General Government hearing.
In her opening statement, DeLauro accused him of “unlawfully impounding or stealing congressionally appropriated funds.”
“You envision a king unbound by laws, who rules by decree, who accepts lavish gifts from foreign governments, who fills public offices with ultra-wealthy and political allies, and who expels opposition and crushes dissent,” DeLauro said. “This view of presidential authority could not be more un-American and more dangerous to our constitutional order.”

title: Education Department seeks to have Columbia University's accreditation removed
description:
The Trump administration said that it has notified the accreditor for Columbia University that the school violated Title VI, threatening the university's accreditation status by saying it "no longer appears to meet the Commissions accreditation standards."
The U.S. Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights (OCR) and the Department of Health and Human Services' Office for Civil Rights (HHS OCR) "determined that Columbia University acted with deliberate indifference towards the harassment of Jewish students, thereby violating Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964," according to press release from the Education Department.

During a press conference, House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., spoke out about Elon Musk's social media post criticizing the Trump-backed budget bill. Elon Musk called the Republican bill to advance Trump’s agenda a “disgusting abomination."
 
Jeffries said of the post: "Breaking news: Elon Musk and I agree with each other. The GOP tax scam is a disgusting abomination. Every single Republican who voted for the one big, ugly bill should be ashamed of themselves. They aren't helping their constituents. They are hurting their constituents."
 
He also spoke out about Sen. Joni Ernst's, R-Iowa, viral comments on Medicaid and on the race for the Oversight Ranking Member role.

title: Can Musk, Altman, and the Tech Bros Capture Human Intelligence?
description:
There’s a good chance that before November of 2022, you hadn’t heard of tech nonprofit OpenAI or cofounder Sam Altman. But over the last few years, they’ve become household names with the explosive growth of thee generative AI tool called ChatGPT. What’s been going on behind the scenes at one of the most influential companies in history and what effect has this had on so many facets of our lives? Karen Hao is an award-winning journalist and the author of “Empire of AI: Dreams and Nightmares in Sam Altman's OpenAI” and has covered the impacts of artificial intelligence on society. She joins “Why Is This Happening?” The Chris Hayes podcast to discuss the trajectory AI has been on, economic effects, whether or not she thinks the AI bubble will pop and more. 

“Why Is This Happening?” is produced by Doni Holloway and Brendan O’Melia, engineered by Bob Mallory and features music by Eddie Cooper. Aisha Turner is the Executive Producer of MSNBC Audio. New episodes come out every Tuesday. Share your thoughts by using #WITHpod. You can also email us at withpod@gmail.com You can see more of our work including links to things we mentioned here by going to MSNBC.com/whyisthishappening.

title: SCOTUS declines to hear challenge to Maryland's assault weapons ban
description:
In a move that leaves Maryland’s assault weapons ban in place, the Supreme Court declined to hear a challenge to the law, over objections from Justices Alito, Gorsuch, and Thomas. The 4th Circuit previously upheld the ban, ruling it aligned with the Second Amendment under the Court’s own history-based test.
On #MorningJoe, Joe Scarborough noted the Court’s pattern of allowing states to regulate military-style weapons: “If the people of Maryland want to ban AR-15s, they have that right.”

title: WATCH: Ukraine hits Russian warplanes in massive drone strike
description:
Ukraine’s Security Service said it has struck at least 40 Russian bombers deep inside Russian territory in what would be one of the largest and most audacious attacks on Russian territory in the years long conflict.
Ukraine managed to smuggle 117 aerial drones on the backs of trucks that deposited them at the perimeter of four Russian air bases — one of them deep inside Siberia some 2,500 miles from Ukraine's borders, according to Ukrainian officials. Some military commentators and pro-Russian bloggers have called it the country's "Pearl Harbor."
It came Sunday, a day before the latest round of direct peace talks between Ukraine and Russia on Monday.

For more context and news coverage of the most important stories of our day click here: https://www.msnbc.com/

title: 'Not as weak as you think': Ukraine carries out massive drone attack on Russian planes
description:
Ukraine’s Security Service said it has struck more than 40 Russian bombers deep inside Russian territory in what would be one of the largest and most audacious attacks on Russian territory in the yearslong conflict. The 18-month plan was unveiled just ahead of peace talks in Turkey.
David Ignatius broke down Ukraine’s covert drone operation—code-named “Spider Web”—on #MorningJoe: “It’s a startling statement… ‘We’re not as weak as you think we are.’”

title: DEVELOPING: Eight burned in attack at Colorado event honoring Israeli hostages
description:
Eight people were hospitalized with burns after a man attacked a peaceful rally in Boulder, Colorado, using a makeshift flamethrower and incendiary devices. The event was held to raise awareness for Israeli hostages held in Gaza. Authorities say the suspect shouted “Free Palestine” during the assault and is now facing terrorism-related charges. One victim remains in critical condition.

title: Brain Drain: How Trump’s policies could wreck American innovation for generations
description:
70 years ago, at the height of the Red Scare, the United States deported Qian Xuesen, a pioneering Chinese-born aerospace engineer. The government accused Qian of being a communist, which he denied. Back in China, Qian continued his work, becoming known as the father of Chinese rocketry and laying the foundations for the nation’s missile and space programs. Former US Under Secretary of the Navy Dan Kimball called Qian’s deportation “the stupidest thing this country ever did.” Now, the Trump administration is seeking to block international students from studying at Harvard, threatening to revoke the visas of Chinese international students, and cutting funding for a wide range of scientific research. This is nothing more than a self-inflicted brain drain, and its consequences, driving the world’s best and brightest away from the United States, could weaken the country for generations to come.

title: Tony-nominated ‘Purpose’ playwright drawn to themes of mental health and Black politics
description:
The Broadway play "Purpose," written by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, won this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama and received six Tony Award nominations. Jacobs-Jenkins speaks about why he felt drawn to writing about dynamics in a Black political family across time: "Parents move through so many moments in history before their children come of age, and part and parcel with that is the evolution of how we've understood mental health. There are syndromes and ideas that very much were alive when I was a child that don't even exist anymore. ... how do we really talk about mental health inside of history that plays out within the generations within a family?"

title: The dire wolf is (kind of) back
description:

But University at Buffalo biologist Vincent Lynch says the results merely recreate the animal’s outward appearance, not the species itself.
Colossal CEO Ben Lamm joined The Beat to explain why they sequenced the genome—and why a real-life "Jurassic Park" isn’t on the horizon.

title: Trump's trade war claims a new casualty: Steel
description: President Trump is launching a new trade war, this time targeting steel, raising the tariffs from 25 percent to 50 percent. CNBC Senior Analyst, Ron Insana and James Sample, a law professor at Hofstra University, break down what it means for business and consumers.

title: MAGA world is big on conspiracies but light on evidence
description: Dan Bongino spent much of his time as a right-wing podcaster bashing the FBI and peddling conspiracy theories, including one that Jeffrey Epstein did not die by suicide in prison. But now that he is the FBI’s deputy director, he is singing a very different tune. The Weekend: Primetime hosts dissect the new reality facing MAGA world.

title: Ernst posts weird non-apology on Instagram after telling town hall 'we all are going to die'
description:
Sen. Joni Ernst's (R-IA) widely-criticized comment came as more Republicans are feeling the heat from their constituents at town halls over Medicaid cuts in Trump's budget bill. MSNBC contributor Paola Ramos and 'Under the Desk' creator and host V Spehar join The Weekend: Primetime to unpack the fallout.

title: Creating MORE undocumented immigrants? How Trump's crackdown could backfire on his agenda
description:
